COMMON.MSG_DETAILS_TABDETAILS_RESOURCEQUOTADETA:
Requests are the amount of resources you expect to use. These are used when establishing if the cluster can fulfill your request.

Limits are a maximum amount of a resource you can consume. Applications consuming more than the limit may be terminated.

A cluster administrator can establish limits on both the amount you can request and your limits with a resource quota.

COMMON.MSG_COMMON_ERROR_MESSAGE_47:
Getting Started
HyperCloud helps you quickly develop, host, and scale applications. To get started, you’ll need a namespace. Currently, you can’t create or access any namespaces. You’ll need to contact a cluster administrator for help.
To learn more, visit the HyperCloud manual.

COMMON.MSG_DETAILS_TABDETAILS_INGRESSRULES_3: Pods accept all traffic by default. They can be isolated via a network policy which specifies a whitelist of ingress rules. When there is a network policy selecting a pod, the pod will reject any traffic that are not allowed by any network policy.

COMMON.MSG_MAIN_POPUP_DESCRIPTION_2: Are you sure you want to delete subject {{0}} of type {{1}}?
COMMON.MSG_MAIN_POPUP_DESCRIPTION_3:
Unschedulable nodes won't accept new pods. This is useful for scheduling
maintenance or preparing to decommission a node.
COMMON.MSG_MAIN_POPUP_DESCRIPTION_4:
This action cannot be undone. Deleting a node will instruct Kubernetes that the node
is down or unrecoverable and delete all pods scheduled to that node. If the node is still
running but unresponsive and the node is deleted, stateful workloads and persistent
volumes may suffer corruption or data loss. Only delete a node that you have
confirmed is completely stopped and cannot be restored.
Are you sure you want to delete {{0}}?

SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEBROKERS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A representation of a service broker for a specific namespace, encapsulating its server connection details. These are created and managed by operators who wish to use that broker server to make new types of managed services available within their namespace.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEBROKERS_CREATEYAML_DIV1_1: Add a service broker made available by a service provider for use in a namespace.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICECLASSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A managed service offered by a particular service broker. When a new ServiceBroker resource is added to the namespace, the service catalog controller connects to the service broker to obtain a list of available managed services. It then creates a new ServiceClass resource corresponding to each managed service.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEPLANS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A specific offering of a managed service. For example, a managed service may have different plans available, such as a free tier or paid tier, or it may have different configuration options, such as using SSD storage or having more resources. Similar to ServiceClass, when a new ServiceBroker is added to the cluster, the service catalog creates a new ServicePlan resource corresponding to each service plan available for each managed service.
SINGLE.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICEBROKERS_MAIN_DESCRIPTI: An in-cluster representation of a service broker, encapsulating its server connection details. These are created and managed by cluster operators who wish to use that broker server to make new types of managed services available within their cluster.
SINGLE.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICEBROKERS_CREATEYAML_DIV: Add a service broker made available by a service provider for use in across the cluster.

Add a cluster service broker to make the service catalog templates available to users. 
To use service brokers at cluster-level, you should use cluster service brokers.
SINGLE.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICECLASSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTI: A managed service offered by a particular service broker. When a new ClusterServiceBroker resource is added to the cluster, the service catalog controller connects to the service broker to obtain a list of available managed services. It then creates a new ClusterServiceClass resource corresponding to each managed service.
SINGLE.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICEPLANS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION: A specific offering of a managed service. For example, a managed service may have different plans available, such as a free tier or paid tier, or it may have different configuration options, such as using SSD storage or having more resources. Similar to cluster service classes, when a new cluster service broker is added to the cluster, the service catalog controller creates a new ClusterServicePlan resource corresponding to each service plan available in managed services.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A provisioned instance of a service class or a cluster service class. They are created by cluster operators to make a specific instance of the managed service available in one or more in-cluster applications. When a new ServiceInstance resource is created, the service catalog controller connects to the appropriate service broker and instruct it to provision the service instance.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DI: No namespace to which you have access permissions.
Select a service class from the namespace to which you have access permissions.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_STEP3_DI: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
At least 2 letters and up to 32 lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters (“-”)
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TAB: Create a provisioning instance of cluster service class.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEBINDINGS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Access credentials to service instances. These are created by cluster operators who want for their applications to make use of a service instance. Upon creation, the service catalog controller creates a Kubernetes secret containing connection details and credentials for the service instance, which can be mounted into pods.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICEBINDINGS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS: Service binding serves to provide the connection between the service instance and application program.
2. Service Binding Secret Key Addition Sample

Service binding serves to provide the connection between the service instance and application program. When the broker responds, the service catalog records the credentials that it responds with into the secret specified in spec.secretName.
SINGLE.MSG_CATALOGSERVICECLAIMS_MAIN_DESCRIPTIO: A catalog service claim allows users to request a new catalog service template from the cluster administrator.
SINGLE.MSG_CATALOGSERVICECLAIMS_CREATEYAML_DIV1: Request a new catalog service by specifying a service template.
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Templates allow users to specify all objects and parameters for an application so that the app may be easily deployed later once the template is created.
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATES_CREATEYAML_DIV1_1: Specify the objects and parameters for an application to create a template.
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_: Defining a template enables you to easily recreate all objects in your application. The template defines the created objects and metadata.
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Template Instances allow users to deploy a new application instance based on the specifications included in the selected service template.
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_1: Enter the parameters required by the template to deploy the application.
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_20: URL (including protocol, ip, port, and path) of private package server (e.g., devpi, pypi, verdaccio, ...)
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_22: Deployment environment variable in JSON object form
SINGLE.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TA: 1. Create a template instance using gitlab-template
Use the registered template (gitlab-template) to create template instances, and select one from the service instances.
2. Create a template instance using apache-cicd-template
Use template (apache-cicd-template) to deploy applications with GitLab CI/CD, and select one from the service instances.

SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Deployment provides declarative updates for Pods and ReplicaSets.

Describe a desired state in a Deployment. The Deployment controller changes the actual state to the desired state at a controlled rate. You can define Deployments to create new ReplicaSets, or to remove existing Deployments and adopt all their resources with new Deployments.
SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPT: Create a Deployment by specifying the container image(s) as well as parameters shown below.
SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_7: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_9: The default entry point of the Docker image and default cmd are overwritten when defining that value.
SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_11: The default entry point of the Docker image is overwritten when defining that value.
SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSCHEM: Deployment enables declarative updates for Pods and ReplicaSets.
Specification of the desired behavior of the Deployment.
Most recently observed status of the Deployment.
SINGLE.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPL: Use the nginx image to create a Deployment consisting of one Pod.
2. Create a Deployment consisting of 3 Pods

Use the nginx image to create a Deployment consisting of 3 Pods. 
A threshold can be set so that the created Pod is ready in 10 seconds (minReadySeconds option).
3. Create a Deployment by configuring rolling update

When you create a Deployment with the rolling update strategy, it upgrades the image by continuing to add 30% new Pods and delete 30% old Pods. 
If no policy is specified, maxSure and maxUnavailable are set by 25% by default.
4. Create a Deployment by mounting volumes

Create a hostPath persistent volume in deployment creation. 
Set a hostpath volume using the real path of the node directory.
SINGLE.MSG_STATEFULSETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
StatefulSets are useful for applications that require one or more of the following:

Stable, unique network identifiers.
Stable, persistent storage.
Ordered, graceful deployment and scaling.
Ordered, automated rolling updates.

In the above, stable is the same property as Pod rescheduling. If an application doesn't need stable identifiers or ordered deployment, deletion, or scaling, you should deploy your application using a workload object that provides a set of stateless replicas. Deployment or ReplicaSet may suit better to the user's stateless needs.
SINGLE.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIP: Manage the deployment and scaling of a set of Pods.
SINGLE.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_5: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
SINGLE.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_8: Set the number of Pods managed by the StatefulSet.
SINGLE.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_12: Create a volume claim in the StatefulSet.
SINGLE.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMP: 1. Create 3 Pods for a StatefulSet by default

Create 3 StatefulSets with unique identities. 
The desired number of Pods can be set by entering the replica value. (Default: 1)
2. Create Pods in parallel when running StatefulSets

Pod management policies can be used to create and launch Pods in parallel.
OrderedReady is the default policy where Pods are created in increasing order and the controller will wait until each Pod is ready before continuing.
3. Set the number of revisions to be maintained for a StatefulSet

The maximum number of revisions that will be maintained in the StatefulSet's revision history.
(Default: 10)
Terminate each Pod, and waits for it to transition to running and ready prior to updating the next Pod.
SINGLE.MSG_SECRETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Secrets let you store and manage sensitive information, such as passwords, OAuth tokens, and ssh keys. Storing confidential information in a Secret is safer and more flexible than putting it verbatim in a Pod definition or in a container image.

SINGLE.MSG_CONFIGMAPS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
Most types of Kubernetes secrets store sensitive information and Config Maps store general configuration information, such as groups of configuration files. Because ConfigMap doesn't store sensitive information, they can be updated automatically, so unlike most Kubernetes secrets that require manual updates and container restarts, there is no need to restart the container.

ConfigMaps accept key value pairs in common string formats, like config files or JSON blobs. After you upload a ConfigMap, any workload can reference it as an environment variable or a volume mount.
SINGLE.MSG_CONFIGMAPS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTI: Decouple configuration artifacts by specifying the required configuration values for the container.
SINGLE.MSG_CONFIGMAPS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSCHEMA: Config Map holds configuration data for pods to consume.
SINGLE.MSG_CONFIGMAPS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE: Write non-encrypted data in a key/data pair. Related data is read from the container.
2. Create Config Map as a file
Write non-encrypted data in a key/data pair.
SINGLE.MSG_CRONJOBS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A CronJob creates Jobs on a time-based schedule. One CronJob object is like one line of a crontab (cron table) file. It runs a job periodically on a given schedule, written in Cron format.

When creating the manifest for a CronJob resource, make sure the name you provide is a valid DNS subdomain name. The name must be no longer than 52 characters. This is because the CronJob controller will automatically append 11 characters to the job name provided and there is a constraint that the maximum length of a Job name is no more than 63 characters.
SINGLE.MSG_CRONJOBS_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DIV1_1: Run CronJobs periodically at fixed times, dates, or intervals.
SINGLE.MSG_CRONJOBS_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DIV2_7:
Schedule Input Method
- Asterisk (*) for all
- Comma(,) is used to separate list items.
- Dash(-) is used to separate the range.

SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
Create one or more Pods and end the specified number of Pods successfully.

An example is to create one Job object to reliably run a Pod. The Job object will start a new Pod if the first Pod fails or is deleted (for example, due to a node hardware failure or a node reboot).

You can also run multiple Pods in parallel using jobs.
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTION_1: Create one or more Pods and have a specified number of Pods end successfully.
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_5: If you specify a label selector which is not unique to the Pods of that job, and which matches unrelated Pods, the Pods of the unrelated job may be deleted, or this job may count other Pods as being completed, or one or both jobs may refuse to create Pods or run to completion. If a non-unique selector is selected, other controllers (e.g. ReplicationController) and their Pods may operate in unpredictable ways.
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_8: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_12: Define the number of retries when the job fails.
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_14: Define the deadline for job execution time. (If the deadline is exceeded, the job is forcibly terminated and changed to a failed state.)
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_16: Define when to delete jobs that have completed successfully. (If not set, the job will not be deleted.)

SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_6: Use activeDeadlineSeconds to specify the active deadline time (10 seconds) of the job. The value must be specified as a positive number.
SINGLE.MSG_JOBS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_8: Specify completions (number of successful Pods) and parallelism (number of Pods to run) to run jobs in parallel.
SINGLE.MSG_DAEMONSETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
Use a DaemonSet when a copy of a Pod always runs on all or specific hosts, and when it needs to start before other Pods.

DaemonSets are similar to Deployments in that they create Pods, and those Pods have non-terminated processes (e.g. web servers, storage servers). Use a Deployment for stateless services, like frontends, where scaling up the number of replicas and updating are more important than controlling the host which the Pod runs on.
SINGLE.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTI: Create specific Pods to run on all or some nodes in the cluster.
SINGLE.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_5: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
SINGLE.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_18: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
SINGLE.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_56: Select the new Pod creation method when updating from the DaemonSet template.
SINGLE.MSG_REPLICASETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A ReplicaSet ensures that a specified number of Pod replicas are running at any given time.

However, a Deployment is a higher-level concept that manages ReplicaSets and provides declarative updates to Pods along with a lot of other useful features. Therefore, we recommend using Deployments instead of directly using ReplicaSets, unless you require custom update orchestration or don't require updates at all.
SINGLE.MSG_REPLICASETS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSCHEM: ReplicaSet ensures that a specified number of Pod replicas are running at any given time.
SINGLE.MSG_REPLICASETS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPL: 1. Run a single ReplicaSet by default

Run the default number of Pod replica (1).
One Pod is executed by default if not specified.
3. Run ReplicaSet Pods after the delay period of seconds.
Run 3 Pod replicas. When creating a replica Pod, it is set to wait 10 seconds (minReadySeconds option) to avoid container crashing. (Default: 0)
4. Run 2 ReplicaSets that match the requirements of the Pod selector
Run the Pods that match the list of Pod selector requirements through matchExpressions as well as matchLabels.
SINGLE.MSG_HORIZONTALPODAUTOSCALERS_MAIN_DESCRI:
The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) automatically scales the number of Pods in a Deployment, ReplicaSet or StatefulSet based on observed CPU, memory, and/or custom metric utilization.

The HPA will periodically adjust the number of replicas in a Deployment to match the observed average CPU utilization to the target specified by user.
SINGLE.MSG_HORIZONTALPODAUTOSCALERS_CREATEFORM_: Automatically scale the number of Pods in a replication controller, Deployment, ReplicaSet or StatefulSet based on observed CPU utilization.
Supports automatic scaling of deployment and replication sets based on specified metrics.
SINGLE.MSG_HORIZONTALPODAUTOSCALERS_CREATEYAML_: HorizontalPodAutoscaler is the configuration for a horizontal Pod autoscaler, which automatically manages the replica count of any resource implementing the scale subresource based on the metrics specified.
1. Create a HPA based on CPU

AutoScaling occurs when the Pod's CPU utilization exceeds 50%.
The minimum number of Pods is 1, and the maximum number of Pods is 3.
AutoScale condition (targetAverageUtilization/ targetAverageValue)
1. Create a HPA based on memory

AutoScaling occurs when the Pod's memory usage exceeds 100 Mi.
The minimum number of Pods is 1, and the maximum number of Pods is 5.
AutoScale condition (targetAverageUtilization/ targetAverageValue)
SINGLE.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DIV: This step covers any basic info required to create a virtual machine. On completing this step, you can already skip everything else to the review before the creation step by clicking the ‘Review and Create’ button.
Run a virtual machine when created.
SINGLE.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEFORM_STEP2_DIV: In this step, you are provided a default network interface. You can select to customize this network interface, add new ones, or remove any of them.
SINGLE.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEFORM_STEP3_DIV: This step shows a list of disks included in the upcoming VM. Depending on the source you have selected in the first step this might be pre-populated with some or no disks.
SINGLE.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEFORM_STEP4_DIV: Fill a form (default) to define a set of common parameters like hostname and authorized ID/Password.
SINGLE.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEFORM_STEP5_DIV: You may review and verify this configuration before creating this virtual machine.
Run a virtual machine when created.
SINGLE.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS:
Create VM objects for CentOS 6 virtual machines.
.spec.template.spec-device and resource settings

HyperCloud allows users to create, add, and manage virtual machines directly from the web console. 
By adopting KubeVirt technology, HyperCloud provides a unified development platform where developers can build, modify, and deploy applications residing in both application containers as well as virtual machines in a common, shared environment.
Create a virtual machine by following the instructions below.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Service is an abstract way to expose an application running on a set of Pods as a network service without having to modify the application to use an unfamiliar service discovery mechanism. Kubernetes gives Pods their own IP addresses and a single DNS name for a set of Pods, and can load-balance across them.
There three types of Services:
- ClusterIP: Exposes the Service on a cluster-internal IP. Choosing this value makes the Service only reachable from within the cluster. This is the default ServiceType.
- NodePort: Exposes the Service on each Node's IP at a static port (the NodePort). A ClusterIP Service, to which the NodePort Service routes, is automatically created. You'll be able to contact the NodePort Service, from - outside the cluster, by requesting <NodeIP>:<NodePort>.
- LoadBalancer: Exposes the Service externally using a cloud provider's load balancer. NodePort and ClusterIP Services, to which the external load balancer routes, are automatically created.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTION: Specify the port and service type to create a service.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_1: 1. Create a service of type ClusterIP (Default).
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_2:
Specify the Pod by a selector. A Pod is created by specifying the service port and target port to be exposed.

A cluster IP (Internal IP) is allocated.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_3: 2. Create a service of type LoadBalancer.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_4:
Specify the Pod by a selector. A Pod is created by specifying the service port (80, 443) and target port (9000, 9443) to be exposed.

A load balancer with an external IP is allocated.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_5: 3. Create a service of type NodePort.

Specify the Pod by a selector. A Pod is created by specifying the service port and target port to be exposed.

You can specify your own nodePort value in the 30000--32767 range. However, it is recommended that HyperCloud automatically allocates a nodePort for you.
SINGLE.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_7: 4. Create a service of type ExternalName.

Map to a service to a DNS names, not a typical selector service.
When looking up the host Example-service.default.svc.cluster.local, the cluster DNS Service returns a CNAME record with the value example-service.com.
SINGLE.MSG_INGRESSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Ingress exposes HTTP and HTTPS routes from outside the cluster to services within the cluster. Traffic routing is controlled by rules defined on the Ingress resource. An Ingress may be configured to give services externally-reachable URLs, load balance traffic, terminate SSL/TLS, and offer name-based virtual hosting.
SINGLE.MSG_INGRESSES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTIO: Specify the host and parameters below to create an Ingress resource.
SINGLE.MSG_INGRESSES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_: 1. Create an Ingress that maps to a service in the cluster.
For inbound HTTP requests, a backend service is required to process the requests mapped to a specific domain and prefix information.
You can add and execute backend services without basic rules.
SINGLE.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: The network policy allows Pod groups to communicate each other or with an endpoint of another network. Network policy resources select Pods by using labels and define rules specifying traffics allowed to the selected Pods. The policy is implemented with network plug-ins and can be used by using a networking solution that supports the policy.

SINGLE.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS: NetworkPolicy describes what network traffic is allowed for a set of Pods.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Persistent Volume (PV) is a piece of storage in the cluster that has been provisioned by an administrator or dynamically provisioned using storage classes. 
A PV captures the details of the implementation of the storage, be that NFS, iSCSI, or a cloud-provider-specific storage system.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DE: Create a Persistent Volume (PV) by specifying the storage class in addition to other parameters. The PV will be available for use by other cluster users.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_17: To use a raw block device, set it as block.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_22: Set the Pod permission to access the volume.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_28: Set a policy for persistent volumes by specifying the storage class.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_33: If you delete unnecessary persistent volume claims, select a policy to handle the remaining persistent volumes.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TA: PersistentVolume (PV) is a storage resource provisioned by an administrator. It is analogous to a node. More info:
1. Create a persistent volume in ReadWriteOnce mode
Mount a volume as read-write in a single node, and delete the persistent volume after use.
2. Create a persistent volume in ReadOnlyMany mode
Mount a volume as read-only in multiple nodes, and not delete but store the persistent volume after use.
3. Create a persistent volume in ReadWriteMany Mode

Mount a volume as read-write in a single node, and delete the PersistentVolume after use. 
ReadWriteMany is applicable only when the block storage class is used and the volumeMode is Block.

To use plug-in type storage, detailed specifications (nfs, mountOptions) are required. After using a persistent volume, you can delete the data and reuse the data in a new persistent volume claim. 
Recycle is only available when plug-in type is nfs or hostpath.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMESCLAIMS_MAIN_DESCRIP:
A PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC) is a request for storage by a user. A PVC can request specific size and access modes.
When none of the PVs match a user's Persistent volume claim, the cluster may try to dynamically provision a volume specially for the PVC. This provisioning is based on storage classes: the PVC must request a storage class and the administrator must have created and configured that class for dynamic provisioning to occur.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMESCLAIMS_CREATEFORM_D: Create a request for a PV by specifying storage configurations.
Set the Pod permission to access the volume.
To use a raw block device, set it as block.
Only persistent volume of the requested class can be bound.
Enter the size of storage to be requested.
You can add a label by pressing Enter.
Specify keys, lists of values, and operators related to keys and values.
SINGLE.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMESCLAIMS_CREATEYAML_D: PersistentVolumeClaim is a user's request for and claim to a persistent volume.
1. Create 1 Gi file storage in the RWX mode.

Create 1 Gi file storage using a storage class. Multiple Pods can be connected and read/written.
ReadWriteOnce: The volume can be mounted as read-write by a single Pod.
ReadOnlyMany: The volume can be mounted as read by multiple Pods.
ReadWriteMany: The volume can be mounted as read-write by multiple Pods.
2. Create 1 Gi block storage in the ROX mode.

Use a storage class to create 1 Gi block storage. Multiple Pods can be mounted as read-only.
(volumeMode: Filesystem (Default)/Block)
3. Create a persistent volume claim in the RWX mode with your persistent volume.

Use the persistent volume (volumeName) you created to create a persistent volume claim in RWX mode. 
The persistent volume claim’s access modes and resource requests must be satisfied in order for the persistent volume and persistent volume claim to be bound.
4. Create a persistent volume claim of the RWX mode to meet the conditions of the selector
Use a storage class to create a persistent volume claim of the RWX mode which will be bound with the persistent volume based on the matching labels.

SINGLE.MSG_DATAVOLUMES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A Data Volume is used to automate the creation and population of a PVC with VM data. Data volumes are more suited for VM workloads over standard PVCs since it provides full functionality, a stable API, and better integration with VM features and capabilities.
SINGLE.MSG_DATAVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPT: Create a data volume by specifying a VM image source and PVC configuration details.

Import a VM image using HTTP URL to create a data volume.
Content type (kubevirt (Default), archive)/ volumeMode (Filesystem (Default), block)
2. Create a data volume using s3

Import a VM image using s3 to create a DataVolume.
ReadWriteMany is allowed because volumeMode is set to block.
3. Create a data volume using a registry
Import a VM image using a registry to create a data volume.

SINGLE.MSG_TASKRUNS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A Task Run allows you to instantiate and execute a task on-cluster. A task specifies one or more steps that execute container images and each container image performs a specific piece of build work. A Task Run executes the steps in the task in the order they are specified until all steps have executed successfully or a failure occurs.

If you do not explicitly specify this, the Task Run executes with the credentials specified in the configmap-defaults Config Map. If this default is not specified, Task Runs will execute with the default service account set for the target namespace.

1) Create a DaemonSet using the image of DockerHub (apache).
2) A resource-limited Pod is created with 0.2 GB of CPU/0.1 Core/Memory on all nodes of the cluster.
2. Create DaemonSets except for the master node

Create DaemonSet Pods using DockerHub (apache) image. Pods with limited resources are created with CPU 0.1 Core/Memory 0.2 GB on all nodes except the master node. (Even if it is a master node, a Pod is created if node-role.kubernetes.io/master does not exist in Taint.)
3. Create a DaemonSet with an update strategy

1) Create a DaemonSet using DockerHub (apache) image, and Pods are created on all nodes that make up the cluster.
2) Can select an update strategy (RollingUpdate, OnDelete (default)) for the Pod image.
3) minReadySeconds sets the waiting time of the created Pod. (Ddefault: 0)

SINGLE.MSG_ROLEBINDINGS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A RoleBinding grants the permissions defined in a role to a user or set of users. It holds a list of subjects (users, groups, or service accounts), and a reference to the role being granted. A RoleBinding grants permissions within a specific namespace whereas a ClusterRoleBinding grants that access cluster-wide.

A RoleBinding may reference any role in the same namespace. Alternatively, a RoleBinding can reference a ClusterRole and bind that ClusterRole to the namespace of the RoleBinding. If you want to bind a ClusterRole to all the namespaces in your cluster, you use a ClusterRoleBinding.

A RoleBindingClaim allows the user to request new roles to be associated with users or user groups.
SINGLE.MSG_ROLEBINDINGS_CREATEROLEBINDINGFORM_D: Associate a user/group to the selected role to define the type of access and resources that are allowed.
Grant the permissions to a user or set of users within the selected namespace.
Grant the permissions to a user or set of users at the cluster level and in all namespaces.
SINGLE.MSG_ROLEBINDINGS_CREATEROLEBINDINGCLAIMF: Request a new RoleBinding by specifying a role and subject.
Enter the name of the RoleBinding to be created through the RoleBinding claim.

SINGLE.MSG_RESOURCEQUOTAS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Resource Quota provides constraints that limit total resource usage per namespace. It can limit the number of objects that can be created in a namespace by type and the total amount of compute resources that may be used by resources in the namespace.

A resource quota claim is a request for a resource quota. Each resource quota claim specifies compute resources like CPU and memory, and a required amount for later use in the namespace. Namespace administrators can approve or reject these claims.
SINGLE.MSG_RESOURCEQUOTAS_CREATERESOURCEQUOTAFO: Set and limit total resource usage of the namespace.
You can add a label by pressing Enter.

You can limit the total resource quota of the namespace by resource type. 
When selecting
SINGLE.MSG_RESOURCEQUOTAS_CREATERESOURCEQUOTAYA: Namespaces are a logical partitioning capability that allows you to specify resource allocation range such as CPU and memory. The claim function is used to enable the resource approval processor.
1. CPU and memory limits for a Pod
Specify requests and limits on compute resources, including CPU and memory, across all Pods in a non-terminal state.
Limit the total amount of storages requested in a namespace, and allows you to set the quantity that can exist in that namespace.

Control a Pod's consumption of system resources based on priority. 
(Values: Low, Medium, High)
(Operator: In, NotIn, Exist, DoesNotExist)

Limit the quantity of resources that can be used based on the specified scope of quota. (Scope: Terminating, NotTerminating, BestEffort, NotBestEffort)

SINGLE.MSG_LIMITRANGES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
An administrator can restrict to create and use resources for each namespace by using resource quota. In each namespace, a Pod or container can use as much CPU and memory as defined by the resource quota. In this case, a single Pod or container can monopolize all available resources. LimitRange is a policy that limits resources that are allocated to Pods and containers in namespaces.

A limit range provides the following constraints.
- Specify minimum and maximum compute resources usage for each Pod or container in a namespace.
- Specify minimum and maximum storage requests for each storage class in a namespace.
- Specify a ratio between request and limit for a resource in a namespace.
- Set default request/limit for compute resources in a namespace and automatically inject them to containers at runtime.
SINGLE.MSG_LIMITRANGES_CREATELIMITRANGEFORM_DIV: Limits resource usage per Pod, container, and persistent volume claim type in a namespace.
You can add a label by pressing Enter.
Set the limit range for each resource type of Pods to be created within the namespace.

Namespaces are a logical partitioning capability that allows you to specify resource allocation range such as CPU and memory. The claim function is used to enable the resource approval processor.

Specify the limits for resources including CPU and memory available in the namespace. 
(Defaults: Default resource quota limits/ defaultRequest: Default resource quota request limits)

A cluster administrator can establish limits on both the amount you can Request and your Limits with a Resource Quota.

SINGLE.MSG_TASKRUN_CREATFORM_DIV2_7: No output resources associated with this task.
SINGLE.MSG_TASKRUN_CREATFORM_DIV2_10: No task parameters associated with this task.
SINGLE.MSG_TASKRUN_CREATFORM_DIV2_12: If not entered, the default value set when creating the task is automatically entered.
SINGLE.MSG_TASKRUN_CREATFORM_DIV2_16: You can set the maximum time in minutes that a Task Run can run. If no value is specified, the global default timeout is used. If the value is set to 0, the Task Run continues without timeout.
SINGLE.MSG_TASKRUN_CREATFORM_DIV2_19: You can execute the task in your Task Run with a specific set of credentials by specifying a service account. If you do not explicitly specify this, the Task Run executes with the credentials specified in the configmap-defaults Config Map. If this default is not specified, Task Runs will execute with the default service account set for the target namespace.

MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_MAIN_POPOVERCONTENTS_:
A Kubernetes cluster is a set of nodes for running containerized applications.

A cluster contains a control plane and at least one worker node.

The control plane is responsible for maintaining the state of the cluster, such as which applications are running and which container images the applications use.
Worker nodes actually run the applications.

You can use this menu to add existing clusters or provision new ones from a variety of cloud and/or infrastructure providers.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_TABLECONTENTS_POPOVER: 외부 환경의 클러스터를 HyperCloud에 등록한 경우, 오토 스케일링을 지원하지 않습니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_MAIN_NODEEDITPOPUP_2: 마스터 노드워 워커 노드의 스케일을 조정할 수 있습니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_MAIN_CLUSTERREMOVEPOP:
{Clustername01}의 등록을 해제하시겠습니까?

등록 해제할 경우, HyperCloud 콘솔에서 해당 클러스터에 대한 어떠한 정보도 확인할 수 없습니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_REGISTERFORM_5: 쿠버네티스 구축 후 생성된 설정 파일 내용을 입력해 주세요.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERGROUPS_CREATEFORM_7: Enter를 입력하여 레이블을 추가할 수 있습니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERGROUPS_DELETECLUSTERGRO:
{ClusterGroup01}을 삭제하시겠습니까?

삭제할 경우, 그룹에 저장된 정보는 삭제되며 그룹에 등록된 클러스터들은 이 그룹에 등록되지 않은 클러스터로 남게 됩니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERGROUPS_REMOVECLUSTERPOP:
{Cluster01}을 {ClusterGroup01}에서 제거하시겠습니가?

제거할 경우, 그룹에 등록된 클러스터 목록에서 사라지며, 해당 클러스터는 이 그룹에 등록되지 않은 클러스터로 남게 됩니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_FEDERATION_FEDERATEDRESOURCEDE:
{FederatedPod01}을 삭제하시겠습니까?

삭제할 경우, 페더레이티드 리소스 목록에서 사라지며, 이미 배포된 클러스터에 대해서도 삭제됩니다.

{n}개 클러스터 중복 선택됨
(중복 선택된 클러스터에 대해서는 하나의 페더레이티드 리소스만 배포됩니다.)
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_INVITEPEOPLEPOPUP_SUB:
멤버를 초대할 경우 초대 알림 메일 발송되며,
24시간 이내로 수락해야만 엑세스 권한이 부여됩니다.

그룹을 초대할 경우, 별도의 수락 과정없이 즉시
엑세스 권한이 부여됩니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_INVITEPEOPLEPOPUP_ERR: 초대할 멤버 또는 그룹을 선택하지 않았습니다.
MULTI.MSG_MULTI_CLUSTERS_MAILFORM_4:
초대를 수락하시려면 HyperCloud로 이동하여 엑세스 권한을 확인하세요.
이 초대 메일은 발송 시간으로부터 24시간까지만 유효합니다.
